msContents.summary:
A Benedictional contains blessings, prayers, and rites intended for the personal use of a bishop. This one was commissioned by
Robert de Clercq Robert de Clercq , abbot of the Cistercian monastery of Ter Duinen (‘Les Dunes’) at Kokside near Bruges from 1519 to 1557, sometime between when he took office and the death of Ludovicus Bloc in 1529. His arms, initials, and motto Sperans gaudebo (‘In hope I will rejoice’) are found throughout the volume. He is portrayed in the Crucifixion miniature (4v), wearing his white Cistercian habit, with his abbatial crosier and mitre. The manuscript was illuminated by Bening, Simon, 1483 or 4-1561 Simon Bening (1483-1561) , one of the foremost Flemish miniaturists of the sixteenth century. It preserves its original covers made by the well-known Bruges binder, Bloc, Ludovicus, (d. 1529) Ludovicus Bloc (d. 1529)

msItem.title: Benedictional of Robert de Clercq
Benedictionale
msItem.note: Miniatures attributed to Bening, Simon, 1483 or 4-1561 Simon Bening (1483-1561) , except those on 69v, 79v. Prayers in later hand inserted at beginning (1-3). Oath of bridegroom given in French and Flemish, 100v-101v

layout.p: 14 lines, ruled in red ink, below top line, rubrics, 2o fol. singulares apud te (2), tuum. tantum (6)

list.item: Crucifixion, including Robert de Clercq kneeling at lower left with mitre and crosier, surrounded by representations of Agony in the Garden, Betrayal, Ecce Homo, and St Veronica with cloth before Christ carrying the Cross (facing text with rubricated heading Oratio sacerdotis ante missam, 4v)
Presentation of the Virgin in Temple (Professio noviciorum, 36v)
Christ blessing and holding orb surmounted by cross (Benedictio ornamentorum ecclesie, 69v)
Baptism of Christ (Ordo ad baptisandum puerum, 79v)
Entry into Jerusalem (2/3 page, In uigilia natalis domini benedictio, 46)
Wedding of Mary and Joseph (1/2 page, Sequitur benedictio super sponsum et sponsam, 98)
Dying man in bed surrounded by his family and a priest (1/2 page, funeral prayer, 102)
Virgin and Child (5 lines, text beginning Certissima spes omnium, 33)

decoDesc.decoNote: Ornamental and minor initials: Brown-gold initials (3-4 lines) formed of knotted branches on blue, green or pink background (5, 17v, 31v, 37, 80); grey-white initials formed of knotted branches on brown-gold ground (1-3 lines)

Border decoration: Various borders framing miniature and text-pages at major divisions and often containing Robert de Clercq’s initials (33, 45v, 46, 97v, 101v), his coat of arms and/or motto ‘Sperans gaudebo’ (4v, 5, 17v, 36v, 45v, 46v, 69v, 102v); architectural designs outlined in gold ink on brown ground (5, 46v, 102v); precious stones and jewellery on violet or pink ground (17v, 69v); oak branches, animals, birds, berries and grotesques executed in brown-gold ink on green or blue ground, or in green and gold-brown ink on plain parchment (33, 46, 101v); tromp l’oeil borders (36v, 37, 70a, 79v, 80, 97v, 98, 102); landscape with birds (45v)
Line-fillers: Brown bars framed and ornamented in gold ink, and filled with white branches and foliage

bindingDesc.p: Original brown leather over wooden boards; stamped with horizontal central fleur-de-lys frieze and four panels containing animals in vine scrolls, each framed by the words ‘Ob laudem Christi librum hunc recte ligavi Ludovicus Bloc’, Bruges binder (d. 1529).

history.provenance: Robert de Clercq Robert de Clercq , abbot of the Cistercian monastery of Les Dunes (Ter Duinen) at Koksijde, near Furnes, 1519-57 (for which see also Nn.3.5); abbey of Les Dunes (‘Liber Beate Marie de Dunis’, front pastedown), where it probably remained until dissolution, 1796; entered University Library by 1798 (appears in James Naysmith’s catalogue, Nn.6.45, completed in that year)

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry derives from Western Illuminated Manuscripts: A Catalogue of the Collection in Cambridge University Library by Paul Binski and Patrick Zutshi, with the collaboration of Stella Panayotova, Cambridge, 2011 (used here by kind permission of Cambridge University Press).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions). Contact the Manuscripts Department for further information on the availability of this manuscript
